review_title: Lack of urgency, understaffing and adapting to new students
pros: -Lie in the heart of Downtown Brooklyn. -Diverse Campus in terms of student population. -Free Parking for employees.
cons: -Students do not feel heard or seen by senior admin. Partly due to admin not mirroring the makeup of the student population. -Senior admin does not act swiftly to student concerns. -Public Safety is not all that safe. -Most of your reachable and visible employees are overworked and underpaid. -The benefits as a whole are not effective (minimal time off given; working up until the last days before a break and immediately after one. -There are talented employees that feel as if their talents and skills are wasted. -There was no sense of community amongst the student population until the new AD of Student Engagement arrived, and even some of those programs are censored. -The lack of explanations as to what the "LIU Way" really is. -STRONG DISCONNECT between LIU-Brooklyn and LIU-Post campuses. Post has more resources and seems to gain the favor. Senior admin work at this campus so they're readily available to address those respective campus needs. -Brooklyn campus is the red-headed stepchild in the "unity" of both campuses. Brooklyn campus constituents also feel left out, forgotten about, pushed to the side, etc. -Housing needs major upgrades. -Brooklyn B&G and trade worker need MAJOR support. Both are understaffed, overworked and underpaid. -Psychological Services needs to be revamped. Students feel unsupported in terms of mental health resources and its visibility. -Communication in terms of what the Promise, Admission, and Enrollment Services offices provide is unclear.

review_title: Tough Job - Worth Doing In The Long Run (Has Great Outcomes)
job_title: Student Success Coach in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Gain a breadth of experience in multiple capacities Work with good people Impact on student's educational experience Learn how to multi-task with excellent efficiency Ability to take experience anywhere (especially within student affairs)
cons: Burnout is going to happen: In this role, you wear a lot of different hats at the same time. How the role is constructed makes it seemingly impossible to get your job done without staying late daily. You are asked to do the job of about 4-5 different people at any other university. Values & Culture: As an institution, LIU does not seem to value its student affairs professionals. They are overworked and underpaid. In this position, I lived on campus, where I had to pay rent and serve "on-call." While other professionals that lived on campus solely paid rent. There is no opportunity for OT, and you are expected to frequently work during evenings and weekends, with in-frequent comp time. The Dean of students often called the office director to ensure staff was working late. You are expected to answer emails until about 9 p.m. Values & Culture: The institution is focused on bringing in as much tuition as possible and does not seem to care about students. As someone who cares significantly about treating students well, this job will create experiences that may directly conflict with the ideal. Diversity and Inclusion: This was only a performative focus when I was here. There is no interest in making belonging a focal point of the university (for students and staff). Senior Leadership: It was clear that senior leadership was only concerned with the bottom line, i.e., how much the university made. Student Support: The lack of student support in other areas of the school makes this job that much harder. The frequent turnover of student support staff makes the students distrustful of the staff in place. Also, the lack of staffing in other areas of the school places a heavier burden on those within the role. There is no interest in fixing the problem from senior leadership.

job_title: Peoplesoft Functional Analyst in Brookville, Nassau, NY
pros: Formerly had great benefits and vacation.

pros: I genuinely can’t think of a single good thing about this university other than the few friends I was lucky enough to make. If you are looking to attend here because it is close to the city and has a high acceptance rate I would strongly advise you to reconsider as you will be sacrificing any kind of decent education, living conditions, and a LOT of money.
cons:
Where do I even start. The education is non-existent and many of the professors are extremely unprofessional. I attended as a freshman in the new RocNation program for only one semester before transferring somewhere else. While none of the programs are of any quality from what I’ve heard, RocNation is especially poor considering it is being sponsored by Jay-Z. I don’t know where that money is going, but it’s certainly not being used to improve the RocNation program or the university in general.

Not only is the education EXTREMELY poor (especially for the amount you are paying), the campus is absolutely foul. While it may look nice in the outside with its greenery, the inside of almost every building is run down and just disgusting. Connolly Hall is literally falling apart, I knew a girl whose ceiling collapsed. The bathrooms were not maintained well in most floors, the 13th floor bathroom has black mold growing in the showers. They often “tested” the fire alarms, even at 3a.m. on multiple occasions, but we never had a single fire drill or were even briefed on what to do in that situation. One of the most concerning aspects of the facilities was the basement of the Metcalfe building which is completely abandoned and run down not to mention unsafe (electrical wires hanging, mold and mildew, crumbling foundations, etc.) , yet still easily accessible to any student who happens to walk that way. I discovered some truly disturbing things down there purely on accident. 

Most of the staff is entirely unhelpful in every conceivable way. If you need to figure something out with a class or financial aid, each person you speak to will just send you to someone else who also doesn’t know what they’re doing. It’s incredibly frustrating. 

The food is absolutely disgusting and there are few options. Most times my friends and I would just end up eating cereal for every meal unless we got lucky and there was mac and cheese or something. The food would get especially bad on weekends which was also frustrating because the only on campus restaurant (Freshens) is closed on weekends, so even if you want to use dining dollars to get a decent meal when the dining hall is especially foul, you cant. I paid $2000 for that meal plan and I mostly ate cereal and sad salads because it was all that was edible.

I cannot stress enough how awful this place is. I could go on and on, there were so many issues that were experienced by many people I knew there, not just me. For example, prior to attending, myself and at least 3 others were told that we would be paying one amount, only to check our LIU portals a couple weeks later to see the price almost DOUBLED with absolutely no explanation (my tuition went from about $7000 to $11000 and the school was, of course, entirely unhelpful). Pres. Kim Cline doesn’t care about anything but robbing young students fresh out of high school and is using the COVID-19 pandemic to further take advantage of them. 

Save yourself a world of stress, emotional and physical damage, and money and PLEASE go literally anywhere but here.

review_title: LIU Treats Employees Like Expendable Waste
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The faculty at LIU are generally hard-working and care about their students.
cons: The administration, led by President Cline, have absolutely no moral compass. President Cline is interested in revenue generation at the expense of quality and integrity. She treats employees like expendable waste. She believes the entire faculty body is "incompetent" and unworthy of participating in any form of faculty governance, she has no problem lying to regulatory bodies, and expects fellow administrators to complete unreasonable turn arounds on projects that typically include multiple levels of input and approvals.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brookville, Nassau, NY
pros: I like my co-workers and there are people here who care and try to do the best by the students, despite the efforts of upper-management to bleed everyone dry. Also, a lot of vacation days, IF you're able to take them all - there's a culture of sacrificing vacation days here.
cons:
Pay isn't remotely competitive, you're expected to do the work of 3-4 people because every department everywhere is sorely understaffed. Corners are cut absolutely everywhere, but the president and C-suite continue to get raises. President Cline is practically Disney villain levels of evil. She publicly accosts employees in front of one another, she micromanages everything possible, everyone cowers in her presence and she fires people after she forces them to do her bidding and it turns out to be a bad idea and fails. She wouldn't let anyone physically near her during COVID (a blessing, I assure you), but would let no one work from home, forcing departments to work in cramped environments and told not to self-quarantine after being exposed to others who tested positive.

This brings me into how COVID was handled, in general. Mass layoffs on day one of NY state forcing the campus to close. They practically punished staff for having to work from home, giving everyone ridiculous, "Productivity," spreadsheets to fill out that had to account for how you spent every minute of the work day from home, with several enigmatic fields to fill in that were never explained. People who didn't fill them out correctly enough were unceremoniously fired. The minute the state opened, we were forced back into our cramped office spaces and given zero masks or gloves. It took weeks for sanitizer to arrive.

I think you get the point. LIU doesn't care about its employees and hardly cares about its students. It currently exists so the president can claim she cut expenditures by x amount and give herself pay raises. Her salary has skyrocketed while many employees haven't seen a raise in over 10 years.

cons: Upper management made all of the decisions for the office which the staff had to carry out without discussing it with the staff first. This usually ended up with a lot of the decisions being changed later on because they did not work and it made the staff look like they did not know what they were doing. There were minimal raises given if any unless you were a relative or friend of upper management and then your salary was in the six figure range . The staff work like dogs and are constantly being told it is not enough they have to do more.  The president continues to fire people who had worked there for 10-25 years or more regardless of their situation and if she did not fire them they quit because they could not stand to work there any longer under her regime. She is a cold, callus person who does not deserve to hold a position in Higher Education.

Late nights for enrollment offices have been extended (from 6:30-8) and from 2 days a week to 3 days a week, and Enrollment offices are also required to be open on Saturdays as well.

review_title: Have low expectations -- and a backup plan
pros: Working with students is wonderful.
cons:
Faculty, staff and student morale at LIU Brooklyn is very low. About half of the faculty has left in the past five years -- whether by retirement, early retirement, resignation or dismissal. 

The Board hired an austerity-minded, top-down president about seven years ago who is running the college like a corporation and slashing budgets, staff, faculty, student support, other resources. Enrollment is down. Staff turnover is high. Faculty participation in governance and program planning is barely given lip service. 

The LIU Brooklyn faculty's contract is up for renegotiation in Summer 2021. When the last contract expired, the president locked out the faculty and immediately cancelled everyone's health insurance -- before the faculty even had a chance to vote on the contract offer. It's the first and only time a U.S. university president has locked out its faculty. She assigned mostly unqualified university staff/administrators to "teach" classes until the contract was resolved, handing out syllabi downloaded from faculty Blackboard pages. 

Leadership claims the school is "recovering from a financial crisis" and promises to start investing in education any day now...

[This reflects my experience at LIU Brooklyn, not LIU Post (Brookville), although leadership is the same; the Brooklyn campus is essentially run from Brookville.]

review_title: I work part time at the Tilles Center for the performing arts at LIU Post and love it.
job_title: Freelance Stagehand/Light/Sound in Old Brookville, NY
pros: The management and bosses are all really great people and so are the vast majority of coworkers there. There are a lot of great shows coming through Tilles and it's fun and fulfilling to be a part of. Very flexible work schedule, freelancing with this concert hall is a great second job. Great work atmosphere, great people, and reasonable pay
cons: One time I signed up for my first and last page turning gig for Joshua Bell. I had no idea what I was doing and got fired from that role by the piano accompanist during intermission. My bosses were all super cool and supportive about it and ripped on me haaha. My heart was racing so fast trying to read classical music(I'm not great at reading music) and turn pages (for the first time) in front of over 2000 people. I look back on it and laugh. In case you haven't noticed by this point, there aren't really any cons to working here, just had to fulfill a 20 word minimum

review_title: Not and easy place to work in my opinion
pros: The students are amazing. The faculty senate is very strong. The location is great. The contribution to retirement (at least according to the last collective bargaining agreement) is very good.
cons: Support for research and academic pursuits had very little support. Even within the college, the support was minimal. For the level of academic pursuit and success that are expected for promotion and tenure are grossly disproportionate to the amount of support (financial and/or release time). Almost to the point of saying that support is almost non-existent.  Additionally, the relationship between administration and faculty is highly contentious. In the last  3 contract negotiations the union went on strike two times and the third, the university locked the faculty out before they could strike. That level of contention is pervasive throughout many relationships outside of contract issues. Notably, the faculty senate has had votes (several times) of no-confidence in the "leaders" of the university. As you might guess, things are a bit contentious.

pros: Brooklyn campus is conveniently located in downtown Brooklyn.
cons: a student retention rate is ~30%; this tells you a lot about the school. Faculty quality is very low at least in liberal arts. A lot of dead wood. They are barely hiring new faculty. School requires 5 publications to get a tenure without adjustment for quality. Research support is almost ZERO. An individual faculty has no research budget for his/her disposal. Department budget has been cut to such extent that there's barely money for paper and photo copier. School is obsessed with Outcome Assessment, which is a complete waste of people time. Facilities are deteriorating; no money on basic maintenance. Moral is extremely low after a new president has been hired in 2012. She has been firing people left and right. Lack of transparency within an organization; president and administration keep everything opaque so nobody can be hold accountable, e.g. organization structure is kept secret by the president. Bureaucracy, inefficiencies, and corruption is wide spread, e.g. there is a committee on committees, entire families of higher rank officials (Provost, Dean, etc) are employed by LIU. LIU is an example of how a university should not be run. School is in a deep financial trouble and I really can't imagine how they will survive another decade or two.

pros: There's great time off - 4 weeks a year for most employees, and some employees get the winter and Easter breaks off as well.  Some positions get summer Fridays, but they took that away for most people.  You can definitely make your job a 9-to-5 type of gig if you want to get home to your kids.
cons: The salary is awful - they charge students plenty to attend, but yet they pay their employees less than CUNY pays its employees.  The Brooklyn Campus is really run down - doors and desks are broken, paint is peeling, etc.  This makes it a lousy place to spend your days.  The surrounding neighborhood is sketchy in some areas.  There isn't much expected of students or faculty here.

pros: Vacation and sick time. Retirement fund options.
cons:
I worked at LIU for a little over five years. When I started, during the Steinberg presidency, employees had great morale. You could feel the energy and positivity through the hallways. That all changed when Cline came in. There were days when she would visit campus and I would act as gatekeeper to her office; the following semester I was abruptly transferred to a different department and I was told it was a 'promotion'. (I'm quite positive she didn't like me because I wasn't a brown nose and didn't stroke her ego).  In my new role, my duties increased tremendously, I was assisting in running an entire program on campus and I was learning a lot, but with greater responsibility did not come greater compensation. When multiple Deans of the college requested my compensation be aligned with my duties, Cline revoked it, each and every time. 

Each year, employees would receive less than a 2% cost of living wage increase. What a slap in the face to hard working, dedicated professionals while upper management pockets big bucks.

review_title: Frustrating with lack of support. Could easily be better.

Concern over expanding class size is resulting in combined classes which do not take into account the students needs, combining 100 and 200 level classes to ensure a higher student to teacher ratio is not a good way to educate students.

Nepotism is alive and well.
there were about 400 lay-offs and now everyone is quitting.

review_title: This Place is Going Down Fast

In reality, the president is protected by the chairman whose divorce was handled by the president's husband. It is misogyny and chaos. Anyone who dares to work there will work 80+ hours a week and will be tied to their cell phone.

pros: Committed faculty.  Opportunity to change for the better.

This created bad feelings on the part of both faculty and students all year long.  Some faculty are not returning next year.  My own area is supposed foster free thinking and new ideas, but the administration is rigid and hierarchical, the opposite of what we're supposed to foster.

review_title: Horrific Institution Profiting Off The Backs of Students
pros:

Some faculty were dedicated to teaching.
cons: Senior leadership was absent and there was no communication. Staff cuts and attrition lead to overworked and underpaid staff. Under performing employees were shuffled from department to department and even after coaching eventually couldn't be moved elsewhere. Faculty were often at odds with one another and hardly present. Disdain between the president, Kimberly Cline, and the faculty remained even 2 years after faculty were locked out. Multiple, immediate demands placed on staff requiring them to work long hours, not be compensated, only for the program to go nowhere and for staff not to be recognized. HR is non-existent and when they can be contacted less than helpful. Turn-over of staff and school leadership is rapid. Faculty are often not granted tenure with no rationale given leading to a contentious environment. Student were lied to consistently which led to their disappointment and dissatisfaction.

Academic departments have been left without secretaries, with faculty members with no idea how to function.  Morale is at the lowest I've seen it in the years I've worked there.  Pay is awful, barely enough to survive on, and more often than not, not enough to survive on.

She has outsourced building maintenance and security. The results are that classrooms and halls are filthy and computer thefts from locked faculty offices has become an epidemic. review_title: Lack of professionalism and lack of regard for employee advancement.

If an employee is terminated, current employees are threatened to not give references or stand losing their own jobs. Infinite excuses for not increasing salaries.

The lay-offs were uneeded; the real reason for the lay-offs was so that LIU's president would have more funds to put into the ridiculous veterinary school on the Brooklyn campus.

review_title: Maybe not paradise lost, but certainly innocence and community of helpful and dedicated people
job_title: Assistant Professor in Old Brookville, NY
pros: The best students and co-workers... but horrible current administration...engaged in criminal dismantling of a wonderful institution
cons: The current administration is engaged in a criminal dismantling of a wonderful institution.  They should be prosecuted before it completes destroys an important educational resource.

review_title: Pros and Cons, A great deal of change, lack of communication
pros: Support for some professional development.  Many good people working here which creates a collegial environment.  Beautiful campus, good benefits.
cons: Lack of plan from upper administration, lack of communication to employees creating negative work environment.  Compensation lower than comparable universities.  Upper administration does not value their employees well, only focus on students

review_title: It had its ups and downs
pros: I loved the people I worked with and it was really rewarding seeing people I helped become students.
cons: They really undervalue the impact of campus tour guides and student ambassadors on the admissions process. From the beginning to the end of my time working their, the quality of leadership received declined and the respect and payment declined with it. It is a shame as it was one of my favorite jobs

pros: Working with an incredibly diverse student body, and some professors who are brilliant at what they do and (more importantly) truly care about their students.
cons:
This institution is morally repugnant, and failing in every possible sense. This university has always had problems, but it's taken a serious downturn. The pay and benefits have been cut from everyone -- faculty, administration, security, etc. The university operates with utter disdain for the students and faculty alike. Morale is at an all-time low.  The goal of management is to break all the unions. They locked out the faculty union, the first time in higher ed history it has been done. 

Furthermore, many people have been fired, three positions have been "consolidated" into one, etc. The result being that people are overworked, and entire departments are starting to fray. My department has replaced the secretary with students on work-study. 

They have also gutted financial aid, including financial aid for veterans. Scholarships have been cut, as have graduate assistantships. The result is a dying enrollment, increasing student resentment, and a steady loss of the better performing students. Those with options have been leaving or not attending. Those without are not being offered the support they require or are promised. 

During tours, the students are told they will have an advisor throughout their time at LIU. The reality is that they got someone with minimal work experience and no knowledge of the student's major for six to nine months, since that is the average turnover of the "promise coaches."

To add further insult, incoming students are not told their financial aid package until they enroll for class. So the only way to know how much it costs to go to LIU is to commit. 

I would be surprised if it is still a university in five years.

pros: Compensation, titles, and location in Brooklyn, NY.
cons:
I left LIU Brooklyn one year ago, and now that all of my close colleagues have left the  institutuion I feel safe writing a review that will not hinder their work. This is the most unhealthy work environment I have ever experienced. During your interview process, you will be told that all you need is passion and a willingness to tackle problems and address change, and that go-getters will be successful there. Please please don't believe this. There is no way a competent, ethical professional can do the necessary work to improve this place until there are significant changes to the leadership at all levels. Your role will constantly change without warning and with zero intentionality. You will be told to complete major projects, and then suddenly be told to do something completely contradictory. You'll be expected to magically make two completely polar opposite things happen at the same time, and will be blamed when you acknowledge that leadership needs to choose one priority over the other. 

This university exists in a silo from the rest of higher education, and best practices are nowhere to be found.  All of the work is financially motivated, not student-centered, and student development theory is completely lacking from all levels of work. Yes, a financially sound instutition is necessary to best serve students, but this reaches new levels. I truly belive this univeristy, which was founded on the promise of opening doors to students of color and immigrants,  preys on students of color by crippling their families with debt and failing to deliver a quality education. This is not to say that the faculty aren't quality, as many academic programs are great, but that the faculty are treated horrendously, and that becuase admission standards are low, students are admitted who cannot succeed and are left with tens of thousands of dollars of debt. Student Affairs professionals are encouraged to retain students even when it is not in the best interest of the physical,  mental, and financial well-being of the student.

These job descriptions will look great on paper. The interview process will impress you and you will feel promised an opportunity to grow with a changing institution and to make a real difference.  Please--for your own well-being and for the good of the field--do not believe the hype. 

If you choose to ignore the warnings and accept a job here, the medical benefits really are great, and you'll be happy to know that the Cigna copay for the therapy you'll most certainly need is only $50 per session.

pros: LIU offers good vacation time even for first year employees (20+ days a year) and a culture of using sick leave so liberally that it functions as additional time off means. So institutionally disorganized that if you stay out of the president's way you can effectively do nothing for years without being noticed, if that's what you want. Finally, the Brooklyn campus is in an area of Brooklyn seeing a huge resurgence which is nice.
cons: There is almost zero room for growth and little chance of having any real decision making responsibility. The president and a very select group of others preside over everything with nearly zero input from deans or other mid to upper level management. Employees are seen as objects and not people and morale is often extremely low especially among those who want to work to change processes. There is also almost no institutional communication leaving employees constantly guessing what the executive strategy is. So disorganized and top heavy it's probably a great way to find out what it felt like living in communist Russia... If t were ruled by the Red Queen in Alice and Wonderland. There's a huge amount of brain train in all offices - good talent typically does not stay there long. Finally, the board of trustees seems to be much more connected to LIU Post and will do anything to prop up a failing campus, often at the expense of LIU Brooklyn (which given its location in a desirable area in NYC has much more potential to  grow).

pros: Tuition is covered depending on which grant you are rewarded. Not too difficult if assigned with a teacher who knows how to teach
cons: Stipend pay is good enough to cover transportation and food, not so much luxury.

pros: My supervisor is very great.
cons: The Provost's family enjoys the best salaries and positions.  We haven't had a raise in years and I am definately underpaid.  My office has received extremely high satisfaction grades.  We have a very small staff and a lot of responsibility.

review_title: Once a fantastic place to work.
pros: A lot of the employees faculty are the best people you would ever want to work with. Some of the smartest individuals you could possibly ever want to meet.
cons:
Administration has their heads in the clouds and their feet deep underground. A lot of people that have been in the institution for 10+ years are being laid off with no notice.
Some of the most oblivious people that you would ever have the misfortune to meet.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brookville, Nassau, NY
pros: It's a beautiful campus and home to many, many great employees that deserve so much more than what they are currently getting there.
cons: I'm a firm believer in the concept of training people well enough to leave, but treating them well enough so they don't want to. In my opinion, LIU is the antithesis of this statement. Since the new president took over, the staff morale is the lowest I've ever seen it. People work the equivalent of 2-3 jobs under 1 job title with a salary that equals just one job. People also often work overtime for no extra pay or compensation. People constantly live in fear of losing their jobs as many have come into work and were fired. I am no stranger to hard work but there has to be a line somewhere. The culture became rude, elitist, and shameful as i`t seemed like more and more people connected to the president were hired. Some serious rumors of corruption exist and if it is true as I suspect, it is absolutely despicable. I also do not believe you receive recognition for all of the work that you do above and beyond your job description and it feels like people are viewed as an expenditure rather than an asset. Although the prior administration was nothing to boast about, primarily characterized by their incompetence to keep LIU financially stable, this one has been appalling in the sense that it completely lacks any sort of human element. The cutthroat corporate culture that many see in the private sector unfortunately now runs rampant through this not-for-profit university.

review_title: Adjuncts beware: LIU Post may try not to pay you.
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Brookville, Nassau, NY
pros: Tilles Center, well kept grounds and historic buildings
cons:
Paying it forward to my adjunct colleagues by sharing this experience:
  
I accepted an assignment letter signed by the HR Department. I received confirmation of sufficient enrollment by the Assistant Dean. After preparing and teaching 2 class sessions I inquired as to why I hadn't received a paycheck (read below my previous experiences in getting paid). The same Asst. Dean who had confirmed enrollment thanked me for my "enthusiasm" and told me I wouldn't get paid because the class was cancelled due to insufficient enrollment. No one informed me or the students prior to my class sessions. 
In 2016 the same situation occurred. In that instance I emailed the corresponding pages in the Collective Bargaining Agreement to the Assistant Dean who investigated the matter with Academic Affairs and I was paid. 
In 2017 there was a delay of 2 months in sending the appropriate paperwork from my department to HR to start getting paid. 

In the last 60 days I have emailed and received absolutely no response from:
- Payroll, HR, the HR Representative who signed my assignment letter
- Every high member of the School where I taught including the Dean and Assistant Dean who asked me to teach and any assistant or secretary that was involved in my teaching appointment and pay
- A LIU Board of Trustee who should be concerned as a former local politician
- A LIU Board of Trustee who is also faculty

I contacted the Union and they have been very responsive to me but it appears that they are being ignored by the school as well.

In conclusion, apparently contracts mean nothing to LIU Post. Please be forewarned.

I will update if and when I receive the correct calculation for my services delivered. However, after all this time and so much correspondence,  I am not hopeful.
